column4: Having trouble with VNC  - How does one go about changing the package used by Ubuntu to server VNC?
Huh? care to rephrase that.
Sorry about that...

Ok. I'm running Kubuntu on a dual PIII with the smp packages and VNC is running with the kfrb package serving up the remote desktop to a PC running VNC Viewer. As soon as you log in via the PC, the screen of the Kubuntu session appears for a fraction of a second, and then the view crashes with a number of different errors.
you are 'shareing' your existing, running desktop eh?
Different errors each time. I've tried checking bugs.kde.org and reinstalling the packages.
Yes, that's right.
may want to not do it that way. :P use tightvnc, or the other vnc server (vnc4server) and have it spawn its own 'desktop/session' of kde.
I have never messed with kfrb myself.
just those 2 other vnc server setups.
How do I switch to using tightvnc? I've installed it for this very reason, but I don't really know how to make this the default VNC service...
Do I simply remove the other ones?
i always just manually run the vncserver.  never used one as a 'default vnc service'
Is there a way to force this service to run on start-up?
thers always a way. ive seen many articals on getting vnc to do all sorts of nice fancy tricks. depends on exactlu what you want to do with it.,
Ok, I'll burrow around and see what I can find... Many thanks!
often i have to read the 'startvnc' scripts to see exactly what stuff they are doing/defaulting to.
Where would I find them?
Nope.. locate startvnc came up with nada...
may be 'vncserver' :P this is whn it pays to actually read the vnc docs and check out the homepages. :P
often i find however that disrtos have 'differnt' setups on their vncserver settings/methods.  some disrtos are vastly different in some ways. :()
I don't know... I've installed tightvnc but it only shows an X desktop, but I need the KDE one...
check th3 tightvnc docs and the server script that runs it - you can make a config file that lets you run any window manager.
the file is often .vnc/xstartup  - but i am not sure what the tightbvnc package for ubuntu defaults to. (check the vncserver script to see wht it looks for)
